conclusion: Problem involves comparing average velocities of two cars using their velocity-time graphs.
Graph is a v-t graph with velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis, showing curves for car A and car B.
Average velocity is total displacement divided by total time taken.
Car A starts at higher velocity v2, car B starts at lower velocity v1; velocities change over time.
To find average velocity, find area under each velocity curve from t=0 to t=t1 and divide by t1.
Area under the curve in a v-t graph gives displacement.
Consider assuming function forms for velocities and integrate to find displacements.
Consider mean value of velocities over time for approximation.
Approximate area under each curve using geometric shapes or definite integrals.
Car A's velocity increases from v1 to v2; curve is concave up.
Car B's velocity decreases from v2 to v1; curve is concave down.
Draw straight lines between initial and final velocities to compare with actual curves.
Calculate area under straight lines as simple trapezoids for comparison.
Car A's curve above straight line implies greater actual displacement.
Car B's curve below straight line implies lesser actual displacement.
Actual average velocity for car A is greater than straight line average; for car B, it's less.
Assume exponential function forms for velocities to express actual areas.
